mainClaim: Removing standardized tests reduces equity and makes admissions more subjective and biased
evidence: UC system study of 225,000 applicants found test-optional policies increased reliance on subjective factors that favor affluent students: recommendation letters (stronger from well-resourced schools), extracurriculars (require time/money), and GPA (varies dramatically by school quality). Test scores were the strongest predictor of first-year college success for low-income and minority students. Schools that went test-optional saw 12% decrease in low-income admits.
supportingPoints: Tests provide standardized measure across vastly different school districts
Free test prep resources have improved dramatically (Khan Academy SAT prep)
High-achieving low-income students benefit most from test score visibility
Holistic review without tests amplifies implicit bias in admissions
limitations: Doesn't address fundamental issues with test design and access to prep. Cultural bias in tests remains a concern. Study limited to UC system - may not generalize nationwide. Suggests reform rather than elimination.
